Author: 610 nami
Review:
It is a temple associated with the Shinsengumi.
It is also famous for the grave towers of the Shinsengumi members enshrined in the Mibuzuka mound on the grounds.
The precincts are very beautiful and there are many photo points. There are also many souvenirs related to the Shinsengumi.
Once a year, a commemorative red stamp book is released, and there are many items that are irresistible for Shinsengumi fans, such as those with a sword design.

Author: Camry 2104
Review:
Be sure to visit Mibu-dera Temple on Setsubun. First of all, you will be overwhelmed by the amount of roasting sold on the approach and everywhere in the precincts. The hoboku, which is dedicated with the wishes of good men and women, is broken at Mibu Kyogen's 'hobokuwari' in April and October. Mibu Kyogen is an important intangible folk cultural asset, and "Setsubun" is performed on Setsubun. I stood in line for an hour to watch it, but the person sitting next to me had come from Tokyo to watch this.
Yamabushi kneading memorial service is also worth seeing. After the dialogue between Benkei and Togashi in the kabuki kanjincho, the yamabushi actually shoots an arrow. It's quite thrilling to jump over a large crowd and fly an arrow to the roof. After that, the Ogoma prayer is held, and the precincts are enveloped in smoke and ash. Ashes will fall on your clothes, so it is better not to wear important clothes.
Of course, you can also see the historic sites of the Shinsengumi, so you can spend quite a long time.

Author: Ë•øÂ≥∂‰∏âÈÉé
Review: In the Risshu sect "Ritsushu", the principal image is Enmei Jizo Bosatsu, and the precincts are enshrined with an overwhelming number of Jizo Bosatsu. Jizo Bodhisattva is the most familiar and closest Buddha to Kyoto citizens, and most neighborhood associations enshrine Jizo Bodhisattva. There are customs to enjoy. There is also a paid nursing home and kindergarten in the precincts, and there is a viewing seat on the second floor of the kindergarten building, and Mibu Kyogen performed in the building across from there is appreciated, so people who can see it must be lucky. Mibu-dera is also famous as a garrison for the Shinsengumi. Many young women worshipers also came. From this area to the Fushimi magistrate's office, there are still many places related to the soldiers, so it's good to walk around and visit them.

Author: ÂÆÖË¶ãËÇá
Review:
You can enter from the front gate, but there are also north and south gates. There are also the main hall, a thousand pagodas, Ichiya Tenjin, Benzaiten, and Mizukake Jizo, but the most famous one here is Mibu Kyogen, which is performed in the Kyogen Hall. Please inquire in advance and visit during Setsubun, Golden Week, and special autumn exhibitions. However, filming is not allowed.
In addition, it seems that Shinsengumi martial arts and artillery training was held, so for fans, we recommend entering Mibuzuka and the commemorative material room. For a mere 200 yen, there is a Shinsengumi tanka monument, a bronze statue of Isami Kondo, and soldiers who died in the line of duty while on duty are buried. Photography is prohibited in the memorial material room in the basement.

Author: Massa S.
Review: Mibu-dera / Mibu-dera The head temple of the Risshu sect. The principal image is Jizo Bodhisattva, and the founder is Kaiken, a monk of Onjo-ji Temple (Mii-dera Temple). The name is known to the world because the Shinsengumi made it their base of operations. A must visit for those who love history. The temple knows this too, and Shinsengumi goods are on sale. it's a good thing. In the precincts, there is a bronze statue of Kondo Isami, the head of the bureau, and Mibuzuka, the grave of Shinsengumi members. Worship while remembering your favorite "Ryu ga Gotoku -Ishin".In addition, the pagoda-style pagoda called Thousand Buddha Pagoda with 1000 stone Buddhas enshrined in a cone shape has a strong impact.

Author: „ÅÇ„Å®„Çä
Review:
Visited on September 6, 21.

In ancient times, it was called Jizo-ji Temple, and "Mibu-dera Temple" enshrines many Jizo Bosatsus such as the principal image, Enmei Jizo Bosatsu, Mizukake Jizo, and Nighting Jizo.

The martial arts and cannon training of the Shinsengumi was held in the precincts of Mibudera.
In addition, Kamo Serizawa, head of the Shinsengumi, was assassinated at the adjacent Mibu garrison (Yagi residence).
For this reason, Mibuzuka, located on the east side of the precincts of "Mibu-dera Temple," contains the graves of 11 members, including Kamo Serizawa and members of the Ikedaya Disturbance. It is

This time, due to the corona disaster, Amida-do Hall, Mibuzuka, and Mibu-dera Historical Reference Room were closed and could not be visited.

The Thousand Buddha Pagoda enshrines exactly 1,000 stone Buddha statues.
You can't enter the building of "Thousand Buddha Pagoda", but the stained glass above the door was beautiful.

"Mibu-dera" is also famous for Mibu-kyogen, a humorous, non-spoken drama that preaches the teachings of Buddha, performed at the Dainenbutsu-do Hall.

Author: Naka Hiro
Review:
In recent years, this temple has gained a high level of recognition due to its association with the Shinsengumi, but its foundation dates back to the 10th century. There are many events with a long history, such as the Setsubun Festival in February, which is 900 years old, and Mibu Kyogen in spring and autumn, which is 700 years old. Compared to that, the Shinsengumi of at most 150 years ago is just a newcomer.
Because it is a temple in Rakuchu, it has been destroyed by fire many times and almost nothing remains of the old hall. On the day I visited, preparations were just being made for the Urabon festival (this event also has a history of 850 years).
By the way, Mibu, which includes this Mibu Temple, is an area where the old-fashioned lifestyle of common people remains strong even in Kyoto. It's an area that has little to do with tourism, but if you have the chance to visit here, I hope you can feel the weight of the existence of this temple, which is rooted not only in the Shinsengumi but also in the local faith.

Author: Kazz Uchida
Review: Mibu-dera Temple is famous for Shinsengumi, but it is said that the temple was built quite a long time ago and is deeply worshiped by the people of this area. You can see the bust of Isami Kondo and the joint graves of the assassinated members of the Shinsengumi, including Kamo Serizawa. There is a museum in the basement, and there are materials about the history of the temple and the Shinsengumi, but it's a bit disappointing.

Author: „Å®„ÇÇ„Åì
Review:
During the consecutive holidays in October, I went to Mibu-dera Temple, which is said to be associated with the Mibu Kyogen and the Shinsengumi. The entrance fee for the temple is 300 yen, and you can see not only the precincts but also the historical materials room in the basement.

Also, since it was during the autumn special exhibition period of [Mibu Kyogen], I also saw [Mibu Kyogen], which has a history of 700 years since the Kamakura period. The viewing fee is 1,000 yen for adults. There are three performances a day, and each performance lasts about 45 minutes, which is quite long.

Mibu Kyogen is a silent drama that wears masks and only gestures, and is characterized by the unique movements of the masked performers to the sounds of gongs, drums, and flutes. Since this was my first time seeing it, I bought a commentary booklet edited and published by Mibu Dainenbutsu-ko, and witnessed representative performances of Mibu Kyogen, such as Tsuchigumo and Dojoji, right in front of my eyes. I managed to understand the content of the silent play that was unfolding ^ ^

The Kyogen performers are also members of the Mibu Dai-Nenbutsu-ko, and they are not full-time employees, but full-time office workers or self-employed people. And.
Also, I learned from this booklet that everyone except the person in charge of dressing the costumes is male.
Thanks to these people, Mibu Kyogen has been passed down to this day.

There are 30 pieces currently being performed. This time, I have only seen three performances, so I hope I can see it on another occasion.

Review:
About 10 minutes on foot from Hankyu Omiya Station West Exit 4 Exit

can walk enough

First, visit the main hall, and when you turn your back to the main hall, you will see a small green garden on your left.
That is Mibuzuka
The temple itself is free to visit, but Mibuzuka requires a small admission fee.
There is an admission ticket office in a small shop

Shimabara is about a 20-minute walk south from here
It's a bit far if you walk, but it doesn't cost 1,000 yen if you take a taxi.
If you go out from the main gate, you may be able to catch a taxi because it is a roadway.

Author: Â∏ÇÊùëÂØøÁî∑
Review:
In 991, Kaiken, a monk of Mii-dera Temple, built a temple in Mibu with Jocho-made Jizo Bodhisattva as the principal image for his mother. seems to have been named In 1213, a hall was built at the current location, but in 1257 it was completely destroyed by fire. In 1259, it was rebuilt as a temple of the Risshu sect and called Hodo Sanmai-ji. Mibu Kyogen, which has been designated as an Important Intangible Cultural Property, is said to have been started by Engaku Shonin in 1300. The temple was destroyed in 1528, leaving the main hall and the south gate, but it was rebuilt shortly afterward. In 1788, the cathedral was completely destroyed by fire, and around 1811, the cathedral, which had been facing south until then, was rebuilt facing east. In 1863, the Shinsengumi was stationed at the nearby Yagi family, and the precincts became a martial arts training ground, which was used even after the camp was moved from Mibu to Nishi Hongan-ji Temple. In addition, there are graves of soldiers. In the Meiji era, the sub-temples declined due to the Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism), and only Nakanobo survived, while the others were abolished.
The statue of Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva in the late Kamakura period, which was the former principal image of Buddha, was destroyed by arson in 1962, and is now an important cultural property of the Heian period in which the standing statue of Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva was moved from Toshodaiji Temple, and is the current principal image of Buddha. there is
On 22/12/31, after climbing Mt. Atago, I was able to visit Mibu-dera Temple. It is understandable that the Shinsengumi used it as a training ground in the large precincts of Kyoto, even though it is located in the middle of the city.

Author: ‰∏â‰∏äÂØøÁæéÂ≠ê
Review:
I only go there during Setsubun, but I think it's a very good temple. It is also a place related to the Shinsengumi, so there are a few displays and amulets for sale. It's not open in the evening, so if you're interested in Shinsengumi, it's best to go early.
When I visit this temple, I always buy flowers, incense sticks, and candles from Mizukake Jizo at the shop. After visiting, the pond behind Mizukake Jizo is decorated with a golden dragon. It is not lit up, so it looks more beautiful during bright hours than at night. The dragon reflected on the surface of the water seems to rise in the blue sky and is very fantastic. Cherry trees are planted around the pond, so it looks more fantastic in the spring, and it seems that the mind is purified. If you are interested in this post, please visit once. Recommended!
There is also a Western-style washroom, so you can stay for a long time! However, there is no toilet paper, so please bring a pocket tissue.

Author: Hiro Naka
Review:

Mibu-dera Temple and Naginomiya Shrine are all rice fields

It is a place where you can forget the hustle and bustle of the city for a while.

Author: Â±±Âè£ÊÅ≠Âè≤
Review:
This temple is famous for the Mibu Kyogen performance of the bonfire. In Kyoto, it is common to visit during Setsubun, and during this time, a bonfire with a wish written on it is dedicated, and the drum seller smashes it in the Mibu Kyogen performance held around the end of April.
It is said that breaking the fire will ward off bad luck and bring good luck, but when you think about it, it seems like a strange twist. There are also Benten, Mizukake Jizo, and Hayakushi in the precincts, but I visited Hayakushi carefully because I was undergoing treatment for a decayed tooth. Ha, ha, I laughed out loud (^^‚ô™

Review: A Jizo temple for warding off evil and bringing good luck. The principal object of worship is Enmei Jizo Bodhisattva. "Mizukake Jizo," which grants one wish by pouring water on it, "Yonaki Jizo," which is said to heal sickness and stop crying in the night, "Ichiya Tenjindo," which is said to bring blessings on academic progress, prosperity of descendants and money It is a temple full of things to see and do, such as ``Bentendo'' which is said to bring good luck, ``Mibuzuka'' where Shinsengumi members' graves and reference rooms are located, and ``Nadeushi'' where wishes are fulfilled.
